Translator: Rhonda Jacobs
Reviewer: Ellen Maloney

11.text:
Before I get to the bulk
of what I have to say,

14.text:
I feel compelled just to mention
a couple of things about myself.

19.text:
I am not some mystical,
spiritual sort of person.

29.text:
I used to be a science
correspondent for NPR.

35.text:
In the course of working
on a story for NPR,

39.text:
I got some advice from an astronomer
that challenged my outlook,

46.text: You see, the story was about an eclipse,

48.text:
a partial solar eclipse
that was set to cross the country

55.text: And the astronomer - I interviewed him,

57.text:
and he explained what was going
to happen and how to view it,

61.text:
but he emphasized that, as interesting
as a partial solar eclipse is,

66.text:
a much rarer total solar eclipse
is completely different.

71.text:
In a total eclipse,
for all of two or three minutes,

75.text:
the moon completely blocks
the face of the sun,

78.text:
creating what he described
as the most awe-inspiring spectacle

86.text: And so the advice he gave me was this:

92.text:
"you owe it to yourself
to experience a total solar eclipse."

97.text:
Well honestly, I felt
a little uncomfortable

99.text:
hearing that from someone
I didn't know very well;

103.text:
But it got my attention,
and so I did some research.

108.text: Now the thing about total eclipses is,

110.text: if you wait for one to come to you,

112.text: you're going to be waiting a long time.

116.text:
Any given point on Earth
experiences a total eclipse

124.text:
But if you're willing to travel,
you don't have to wait that long.

128.text:
And so I learned
that a few years later, in 1998,

132.text:
a total eclipse was going
to cross the Caribbean.

136.text:
Now, a total eclipse is visible
only along a narrow path,

141.text: and that's where the moon's shadow falls.

148.text:
the path of totality
was going to cross Aruba.

151.text:
So I talked to my husband,
and we thought, well, February? Aruba?

156.text: Sounded like a good idea anyway.

161.text:
to enjoy the sun
and to see what would happen

164.text: when the sun briefly went away.

166.text:
Well, the day of the eclipse
found us and many other people

173.text: waiting for the show to begin.

174.text:
And we wore eclipse glasses
with cardboard frames

178.text:
and really dark lenses that enabled us
to look at the sun safely.

183.text:
And a total eclipse
begins as a partial eclipse,

187.text:
as the moon very slowly
makes its way in front of the sun.

191.text:
So first it looked like the sun
had a little notch in its edge,

195.text:
and then that notch grew
larger and larger,

198.text: turning the sun into a crescent.

201.text:
And it was all very interesting,
but I wouldn't say it was spectacular.

204.text: I mean, the day remained bright.

206.text:
If I hadn't known
what was going on overhead,

209.text: I wouldn't have noticed anything unusual.

213.text:
Well, about ten minutes before
the total solar eclipse was set to begin,

224.text:
Daylight looked odd,
and shadows became very strange;

230.text:
as if someone had turned up
the contrast knob on TV.

235.text:
And then I looked offshore,
and I noticed running lights on boats,

239.text:
so clearly it was getting dark,
although I hadn't realized it.

243.text:
Well soon, it was obvious
it was getting dark.

245.text: It felt like my eyesight was failing.

248.text: And then all of the sudden,

254.text: a cheer erupted from the beach,

257.text: and I took off my eclipse glasses,

259.text:
because at this point
during the total eclipse,

262.text:
it was safe to look at the sun
with the naked eye.

274.text:
Now, consider that, at this point,
I was in my mid-30s.

279.text: I had lived on Earth long enough

283.text: to know what the sky looks like.

289.text: I'd seen blue skies and grey skies,

292.text: and starry skies and angry skies,

299.text: But here was a sky I had never seen.

303.text: So first, there were the colors.

306.text: Up above, it was a deep purple-grey,

310.text: But on the horizon, it was orange,

315.text: And up above, in the twilight,

318.text: bright stars and planets had come out.

326.text: And they were all in a line.

339.text:
It looked like a wreath
woven from silvery thread,

343.text:
and it just hung out there
in space, shimmering.

349.text: Now, that was the sun's outer atmosphere,

355.text: And pictures just don't do it justice.

357.text:
It's not just a ring or halo
around the sun;

362.text:
it's finely textured,
like it's made out of strands of silk.

367.text:
And although it looked
nothing like our sun,

369.text: of course, I knew that's what it was.

371.text:
So there was the sun,
and there were the planets,

375.text:
and I could see how the planets
revolve around the sun.

379.text: It's like I had left our solar system

382.text:
and was standing on some alien world,
looking back at creation.

388.text: And for the first time in my life,

390.text:
I just felt viscerally connected
to the universe

399.text: or it just kind of felt nonexistent,

402.text: and what I beheld with my eyes -

411.text: And I stood there in this nirvana

414.text:
for all of 174 seconds -
less than three minutes -

420.text: when all of the sudden, it was over.

425.text:
the stars and the planets
and the corona were gone,

434.text: And that's how I became an umbraphile -

441.text:
And so, this is how I spend my time
and hard-earned money.

446.text:
Every couple of years, I head off
to wherever the moon's shadow will fall

455.text: and to share the experience with others:

460.text: with an entire city in Germany.

462.text:
In 1999, in Munich,
I joined hundreds of thousands

467.text: who filled the streets and the rooftops,

469.text:
and cheered in unison
as the solar corona emerged.

475.text: And over time, I've become something else:

480.text: I see it as my job

483.text:
to pay forward the advice
that I received all those years ago.

488.text: And so let me tell you:

494.text:
you owe it to yourself
to experience a total solar eclipse.

499.text: It is the ultimate experience of awe.

504.text:
Now, that word, "awesome,"
has grown so overused

508.text: that it's lost its original meaning.

510.text:
True awe, a sense of wonder
and insignificance

515.text:
in the face of something
enormous and grand,

519.text: But when you experience it, it's powerful.

528.text:
Indeed, it promotes
empathy and generosity.

532.text:
Well, there is nothing truly more awesome
than a total solar eclipse.

537.text:
Unfortunately, few Americans
have seen one,

542.text:
since one last touched
the continental United States,

545.text:
and 99 years since one last crossed
the breadth of the nation.

550.text: But that is about to change.

556.text:
five total solar eclipses will visit
the continental United States,

560.text:
and three of them
will be especially grand.

564.text: Six weeks from now, on August 21st, 2017 -

572.text:
the moon's shadow will race
from Oregon to South Carolina.

576.text:
April 8th, 2024, the moon's shadow
heads north from Texas to Maine.

584.text: the path cuts from California to Florida.

591.text: What if we made these holidays?

599.text: What if we all stood together,

606.text: in the shadow of the moon?

608.text:
Just maybe, this shared experience of awe
would help heal our divisions,

614.text:
get us to treat each other
just a bit more humanely.

618.text:
Now, admittedly, some folks consider
my evangelizing a little out there;

627.text:
I mean, why focus so much attention
on something so brief?

632.text:
Why cross the globe -
or state lines, for that matter -

635.text: for something that lasts three minutes?

642.text: I am not a spiritual person.

650.text: But when I think of my own mortality -

656.text: when I think of everyone I have lost,

665.text: is that moment of awe I had in Aruba.

668.text: I picture myself on that beach,

674.text: and I remember how I felt.

681.text: but that's okay because, my gosh,

683.text: look at what I'm a part of.

687.text: And so this is a lesson I've learned,

689.text:
and it's one that applies
to life in general:

693.text:
Duration of experience
does not equal impact.

697.text:
One weekend, one conversation -
hell, one glance -

705.text:
Cherish those moments
of deep connection with other people,

709.text:
with the natural world,
and make them a priority.

717.text: But it's not about the 174 seconds.

721.text:
It's about how they change
the years that come after.
